entry.title: Efficient Ab initio Method for Calculations of Electron-Defect Scattering
entry.content:
Efficient Ab initio Method for Calculations of Electron-Defect Scattering

Introduction

As is known to all, electron-phonon interactions govern charge carriers dynamics at room temperature, where they play intrinsic roles in limiting carrier mobility.On the other hand, just like phonons, defects in materials can also scatter or capture charge carriers. They become significant for carrier dynamics at low temperature,where phonons are frozen out.

However, first-principle calculations of electron-defect interactions are still in their infancy. Those calculations need large supercells to obtain the electron wave function and defect perturbation potentials, which may lead huge computational cost. Here, I’d like to introduce a more efficient scheme to compute the electron-defect scattering matrix elements. This approach is firstly proposed by Bernardi’s group at Caltech, and it dose not require the wave functions of large supercells, which dramatically accelerates the calculations.

Methodology

The electron-defect scattering matrix elements $M_{n^{\prime} k^{\prime} , nk}$ encode the probability amplitude from the unperturbed state $|nk\rangle$ to $|n^\prime k^\prime \rangle$ due to the perturbation potential $\Delta V_{e-d}$ from a defect:
$$
M_{n^{\prime} k^{\prime} , nk} = \langle n^\prime k^\prime | \Delta V_{e-d} | nk\rangle
$$

entry.title: Valleytronics in Two-dimensional systems
entry.content:
Valleytronics in Two-dimensional systems

Valley

In analogy to charge for electronics and spin for spintronics, valley, as a new degree of freedom for electrons, can be utilized to encode and process information, which is characterized as Valleytronics and has drawn considerable attention due to its significant potential for developing next-generation minimized devices.

The valley refers to a local energy minimum (maximum) in conduction (valence) band at the K and K’ points in the first Brillouin Zone, which is robust against phonon and defect scatterings due to the large separation in the momentum space. Therefore, two-dimensional materials with hexagonal lattice should be the most competitive candidates to be applied in valleytronic devices.

Valley polarization

In order to distinguish non-equivalent valleys, the major challenage in two-dimensional valley materials is to break the degeneracy between the valleys, thus forming the valley polarization, which opens a window for capturing the valley degree of freedom and is indispensable for valleytronic applications. The degeneracy between valleys results in the protections of inversion symmetry and time-reversal symmetry. Therefore, monolayers of 2H-phase transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are the most promising candidates for valley polarization, since the inversion symmetry for their structures is explicitly broken, and noncentrosymmetry together with intrinsic spin-orbit coupling (SOC) derived from the d orbitals of heavy transition metals lead spin and valley degree of freedom couple strongly. As a result, in TMDs monolayers, it is very fundamental and effective to introduce an external magnetic field to break the time-reversal symmetry and induce valley splitting. Unfortunately, the extreme field strength for a sizable valley splitting is not accessible in practice use. To explore intrinsic valley polarization in TMDs is thus highly desirable.

Ferrovalley property

In analogy to ferroelectric materials with spontaneous charge polarization, or ferromagnetic materials with spontaneous spin polarization, here we introduce a new member of ferroic family, that is, a ferrovalley material with spontaneous valley polarization.

we rebuild the Hamiltonian for the classical monolayers of TMDs, and point out that the coexistence of the SOC effect and exchange interaction of localized d electrons is the sufficient condition for spontaneous valley polarization in this kind of systems.
